statement: D. Min Cost Stringtime limit per test2 secondsmemory limit per test256 megabytesinputstandard inputoutputstandard outputLet's define thecostof a string $$$s$$$ as the number of index pairs $$$i$$$ and $$$j$$$ ($$$1 \\le i < j < |s|$$$) such that $$$s_i = s_j$$$ and $$$s_{i+1} = s_{j+1}$$$.You are given two positive integers $$$n$$$ and $$$k$$$. Among all strings with length $$$n$$$ that contain only the first $$$k$$$ characters of the Latin alphabet, find a string with minimum possiblecost. If there are multiple such strings with minimumcost— find any of them.InputThe only line contains two integers $$$n$$$ and $$$k$$$ ($$$1 \\le n \\le 2 \\cdot 10^5; 1 \\le k \\le 26$$$).OutputPrint the string $$$s$$$ such that it consists of $$$n$$$ characters, each its character is one of the $$$k$$$ first Latin letters, and it has the minimum possiblecostamong all these strings. If there are multiple such strings — print any of them.ExamplesInput9 4OutputaabacadbbInput5 1OutputaaaaaInput10 26Outputcodeforces

processed.result:
You are given two numbers,  $n$ and $k$.  

You need to find the shortest string of length $n$ made up of the first $k$ letters of the alphabet (a, b, c, ..., z) that has the fewest repeating pairs of letters.

A repeating pair is defined as two letters in the string that are the same, and the letters next to them are also the same. For example, in the string "abacadbb", the pairs "ab" and "ad" are repeating pairs.

Print one such string with the fewest repeating pairs. If there are multiple strings with the fewest repeating pairs, you can print any one of them.
You are given a length and a number of characters. Find the shortest string of that length using only those characters that has the fewest repeating pairs of characters.
